['In mathematics, cardinal numbers are used to describe the number of elements in a set or the size of a collection.', 'Countable sets: The set of natural numbers (1, 2, 3, etc.) is an example of a countable set, which means that the set can be put into one-to-one correspondence with the set of integers', 'Uncountable sets: The set of real numbers is an example of an uncountable set, which means that there are unboundedly many real numbers and no way to put them into one-to-one correspondence with the set of integers', 'Finite sets: A finite set is a set with a fixed number of elements', 'Infinite sets: An infinite set is a set with an unbounded number of elements', 'Cardinality: The cardinality of a set is its cardinal number, which can be either finite or infinite', 'Ordered sets: An ordered set is a set in which the elements are arranged in a specific order, such as the set of real numbers with the standard ordering', 'Well-orderable sets: A well-orderable set is a set that can be put into a one-to-one correspondence with the set of integers in a specific order', 'Countably infinite sets: A countably infinite set is a set whose elements can be put into a one-to-one correspondence with the set of integers', 'Uncountably infinite sets: An uncountably infinite set is a set whose elements cannot be put into a one-to-one correspondence with the set of integers', 'Cardinality inequality: The cardinality inequality states that if two sets have the same cardinal number, then they must have the same size', 'There are different types of cardinal numbers, including countable and uncountable sets, finite and infinite sets, well-orderable and unwell-orderable sets, and countably and uncountably infinite sets']
